awd_titl_txt: CRII: AF: The Polynomial Method in Learning, Communication, and Quantum Computation
awd_abstract_narration:
Modern computing offers exciting paradigms for processing and analyzing large datasets. Machine learning, data-stream analytics, and quantum computing have revolutionized areas ranging from electronic commerce, to bioinformatics, to the development of secure cryptosystems. This project takes a unified approach toward understanding both the power and the fundamental limitations of each of these computing paradigms. Tasks which can be performed efficiently in each of these models correspond to mathematically simple objects, namely, functions which can be approximately represented by low-degree polynomials. The goals of this project are to understand which functions have these simple representations and to identify specific new implications of this understanding within each of the aforementioned areas. Students of all levels will play an essential role in carrying out this research and will be engaged in a broad cross-section of research areas within the foundations of computer science.

There are two main technical components of this research project. The first component will hone the body of techniques for understanding two measures of how well functions can be approximated by low-degree polynomials: approximate degree and threshold degree. These notions already suffice to capture how polynomial approximations arise in many areas of computing. This research will strengthen and improve the versatility of the "method of dual polynomials," a method for proving lower bounds on these quantities that is based on linear programming duality. The second component will lay foundations for applying these techniques to more general objects, including sets of and distributions over polynomial representations. These more general objects more accurately capture powerful models in machine learning and quantum computing, against which techniques for proving lower bounds are lacking, but seem necessary to tackle longstanding open questions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The main research goal of this project was to employ the "polynomial method" as a unified approach to understanding the capabilities and limitations of the fundamental abstract computing devices arising in quantum computing, machine learning, and communication complexity.


This grant supported the PI's publication of five journal articles and twelve peer-reviewed publications in selective conferences, as well as two additional papers by PhD students in his research group. One of these results is a near-optimal approximate degree lower bound for the "ordered search" problem. This establishes a sense in which polynomial approximations are incapable of improving upon binary search. Moreover, the new techniques based on communication complexity arguments led to a framework for proving lower bounds against a broader class of oracle identification problems. Additional research results include new lower bounds on the extent to which accurate learning algorithms must retain information about the training examples they are given, as captured by information-theoretic measures of "memorization" and by space complexity in the streaming model.


Another major goal of the project was to enable the synthesis of recent research on approximate degree and its dissemination to appropriate audiences. This was accomplished through a technical survey on Approximate Degree in Classical and Quantum Computing that appeared in the SIGACT News Complexity Column, as well as a much more extensive and deeper monograph on the topic appearing in the Foundations and Trends in Theoretical Computer Science book series.


This project also contributed to the PI's educational mission, leading to the development of a graduate topics course on Mathematical Methods for Theoretical Computer Science, as well as curriculum development for core undergraduate and graduate courses on Theory of Computation and Computational Complexity. It also supported the training of PhD students, as well as the PI's outreach efforts in making some of the mathematical concepts underlying modern security and privacy research accessible to K-12 students.
